patterns.name: Multi-Select Parameters
patterns.description: Multiple color selections create exponential URL combinations (2^N). These are blocked via robots.txt to prevent crawl waste.
patterns.explanation: When users select multiple values like color=black,blue, each combination creates a unique URL. With 5 colors selected, you get 2^5 = 32 possible URLs.
whenToAvoid: Always use single-select or separate pages
Avoid checkbox multi-select without proper blocking
patterns.implementation: Detect comma-separated values and return robots blocked status

patterns.name: Multiple Stable Filters
patterns.description: Combining stable filters like color + size creates N√óM URLs. Uses noindex,follow to prevent index bloat while maintaining discoverability.
patterns.explanation: 5 colors √ó 4 sizes = 20 URL variations. Risk of index bloat but manageable with proper robots directives.
patterns.strategy: Apply noindex,follow with canonical to single-filter version
patterns.implementation: Detect 2+ stable parameters and set robots to noindex,follow

patterns.name: Single Stable Filter
patterns.description: Single filters like color=black represent real user intent with limited variations. These are index,follow and ideal for clean path conversion.
patterns.explanation: Linear growth (one URL per value). Safe to index as they represent meaningful product segments.
whenToUse: When users search for specific attributes
As candidates for clean path conversion
patterns.strategy: index,follow OR convert to clean path for better keywords
patterns.implementation: Single stable parameter gets index,follow by default

patterns.name: Gender Filter
patterns.description: Gender-based clean paths create stable product segmentation. Ideal for e-commerce with clear gender differentiation.
patterns.explanation: 4 gender options (women, men, girls, boys) create 4 valuable landing pages per category.
whenToUse: Significant product count per gender (10+ products)
whenToAvoid: Gender not relevant to product type
patterns.strategy: Clean path with index,follow and static generation
patterns.implementation: Use generateStaticParams to pre-render gender pages

patterns.name: Sort Parameters
patterns.description: Sorting changes layout but not content. Use noindex,follow or create curated clean paths for high-value sorts.
patterns.explanation: Sorted pages create duplicate content. Blocking allows discovery without indexing variations.
whenToUse: To allow crawler discovery of products
When you need link equity flow
whenToAvoid: Avoid when sort doesn't change content significantly
patterns.implementation: Mark sort parameter as unstable to trigger noindex,follow

patterns.name: View Preferences
patterns.description: Layout preferences like grid/list view are purely UI state and should be blocked from indexing.
patterns.explanation: View parameters don't change content, only presentation. Should never be indexed.
whenToAvoid: Avoid putting in URLs if possible
patterns.implementation: Add view parameter to blocked policy in rules.json

patterns.name: Price Ranges
patterns.description: Numeric ranges like price_min/max create infinite URLs. Always blocked via robots.txt to protect crawl budget.
patterns.explanation: Any combination of min/max values creates a unique URL. Potentially infinite combinations.
patterns.strategy: Always block via robots.txt: Disallow: /*?*price_min=*, Disallow: /*?*price_max=*
patterns.implementation: Mark price_min and price_max as blocked in parameter rules

patterns.name: Date Ranges
patterns.description: Date range filters create infinite URL combinations and should always be blocked from crawlers.
patterns.explanation: Similar to price ranges, date parameters create unlimited URL variations.
whenToAvoid: Avoid in public URLs if possible
patterns.implementation: Add date parameters to blocked policy

patterns.name: Clean Path Routes
patterns.description: Convert stable parameters to clean paths for better SEO. Example: /for/women/ instead of ?gender=women.
patterns.explanation: Semantic URLs are better for keywords, user intent, and click-through rates.
whenToUse: Stable filters with high search volume
When SEO is priority over flexibility
patterns.strategy: Static generation with generateStaticParams at build time
patterns.implementation: Create [param] routes with validation and static generation

patterns.name: Path Parameters
patterns.description: Dynamic path segments for product pages. Always indexable with proper metadata and content.
patterns.explanation: Product pages are core content and should always be indexed with unique titles and descriptions.
patterns.implementation: Use Next.js dynamic routes with unique content

patterns.name: Query Parameters
patterns.description: Traditional query strings with parameter classification. Indexability depends on parameter policy.
patterns.explanation: Query params are flexible but require careful SEO policy: stable, unstable, or blocked.
whenToAvoid: When clean paths would work better

patterns.name: Pagination
patterns.description: Page 2+ creates duplicate content. Use noindex,follow to prevent indexing while allowing discovery.
patterns.explanation: Page 1 is indexable, page 2+ uses noindex,follow to avoid duplicate content issues.
whenToAvoid: Don't canonical all pages to page 1
patterns.implementation: Detect page parameter >= 2 and set noindex,follow

patterns.name: Breadcrumb Navigation
patterns.description: Structured internal linking that helps both users and search engines understand site hierarchy.
patterns.explanation: Breadcrumbs improve UX and provide valuable internal links and structured data.
whenToAvoid: Never hide from users or search engines
patterns.strategy: Always beneficial for SEO and UX

patterns.name: Faceted Navigation
patterns.description: Multi-dimensional filtering requires careful parameter classification to avoid crawl traps.
patterns.explanation: Faceted nav creates many URL combinations. Success depends on proper parameter policies.
patterns.strategy: Careful parameter classification and canonical strategy
patterns.implementation: Define stable, unstable, and blocked parameters

patterns.name: Protected Routes
patterns.description: User-specific pages like account areas should be noindex,nofollow and blocked via robots.txt.
patterns.explanation: Private user data should never be indexed or crawled by search engines.

patterns.name: Search Pages
patterns.description: Search result pages are thin content but allow discovery. Use noindex,follow.
patterns.explanation: Search pages don't add unique value but help crawlers discover content.

patterns.name: API Routes
patterns.description: System endpoints should be blocked except for specific routes like /api/robots and /api/sitemap.
patterns.explanation: APIs aren't meant for search engines, except specific SEO endpoints.
whenToAvoid: Never expose API endpoints to crawlers
